text: imagine it 120,000 of any kind of animal
just died within a couple of weeks
120,000 crows just fell from their
perches or out of the sky in your part
of the world that would be sad and
strange in totally terrifying if a
hundred and twenty thousand dolphins
washed up on the shore it would be an
ecological calamity now imagine if those
120,000 dead animals accounted for
almost half of that species entire
population on earth well that's exactly
what's happening with the Saiga a weird
and unique kind of antelope found on the
cold steppes of Central Asia they're
downright prehistoric looking animals
with giant eyes and floppy trunk like
snouts and they're basically like living
fossils having grazed around Asia for
around five million years has it last
year there were about 260,000 Saiga in
Asia mostly in Kazakhstan but suddenly
beginning around May 10th they started
dying in huge numbers within about 10
days the toll was 27,000 then a few days
later 80,000 and then the Kazakh
government contacted the UN for help
figuring out what was going on the UN's
Convention on migratory species sent a
team of British biologists to
investigate and so far they still don't
know what's killing the Saiga even as
the death toll has exceeded 120,000 the
outbreak seems to have started after
females gathered into herds in early May
as they usually do to give birth but
suddenly hundreds of the females and
their young started dying after showing
symptoms like foaming at the mouth
diarrhea and difficulty breathing
at first some people thought that the
disease had to do with unusually heavy
spring rains others suggested that the
Saiga had started grazing on toxic weeds
that were being spurred on by warm wet
weather other experts even considered
the effects of recent rocket launches
like leaking fuel since Kazakhstan is
the home of the Russian Federation is
launched in landing sites but the UN
researchers told new scientists that
they think part of the cause may be an
infection of the blood known as
hemorrhagic septicemia this disease has
been known to devastate herds of animals
like cattle buffalo and bison often in
as little as eight hours after symptoms
start to appear and with a mortality
rate of 100 percent this seems like a
likely culprit since blood-borne
infection could easily sweep through a
large group of animals giving birth
around the same time but the biologist
said the bacteria that usually causes
this kind of an effect
called Pasteurella aren't necessarily
dangerous on their own around five
percent of most cattle and Buffalo for
instance are walking around with
Pasteurella at any given time so there
must be something else that's weakening
the Saiga's immune systems and allowing
the bacteria to take over what that is
whether it's another bacterium or a
virus or just a sudden change in the
weather just isn't clear and neither is
how scientists can stop it but on the
other side of the world another equally
endangered and ancient-looking animal
seems to have found a strategy for
survival and it's never been documented
until now small-tooth sawfish in florida
have been found to give birth to young
without ever having mated the first time
that so-called virgin births have been
recorded in the wild among animals that
could reproduce sexually if they wanted
to biologists were studying the DNA of
sawfish in southwestern Florida when
they discovered that about 3% of the
population were not quite clones but
strange kind of copies of their mothers
it turned out that some of the female
fish had been undergoing parthenogenesis
where reproducing by using unfertilized
eggs we talked before about how some
animals can have babies without having
sex it's pretty common in invertebrates
like insects but in vertebrates it's
only been observed in some reptiles and
birds and sharks in captivity or some
other kind of isolation when no males
were available for a female to mate with
in the case of the sawfish there were
some guys for the ladies to choose from
but the population was really small in
fact the scientists were studying that
particular group because they wanted to
know if members of the same families
were mating with each other but
apparently the females found an
alternative parthenogenesis is thought
to begin when a progenitor cell in a
female kind of like a proto egg divides
to create a single egg along with three
leftover sister cells but instead of
taking in a sperm cell the egg just
absorbs one of the sister cells they can
combine their genetic material and
divide to create an embryo the result is
what biologists call a half clone while
the mother had two sets of chromosomes
that had inherited from its parents its
offspring winds up with two identical
copies of just one of those sets
researchers say that while biologically
ingenious the fact that the sawfish are
reproducing this way may be a sign of
how depleted their numbers have become
because of overfishing and habitat loss
I mean if it's a choice between asexual
reproduction and total extinction which
one would you choose
if there's any sense of the news that
